displayed_text: Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic. Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: No, I don’t think so. Doctor: Well then next time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh the, I don’t know if they come back yet. I saw that… Patient: And I had a bone density done . And I sent that to her, I don’t know if you saw that? Doctor: Uh and G___ is what kind of doctor? Patient: Uh he’s my oncologist Patient: I’m presuming no. where I uh had the scans done Doctor: I’ll ask about it. My sense is don’t order a lot of those tests because Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you not having any bone or physical symptoms If it meets the threshold, they can give you a pill Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so

Family Member: Right. Doctor: But I also would prefer the two of you be the voice, you know. ‘Cuz for me to go over it four different times just because -- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Someone’s not able to get here makes it difficult. Family Member: Right. Patient: Well she has court today. Her ex-husband is – Family Member: Being a pain in the ass. Patient: He wants more custody of the kids. So, she has her own mess. Doctor: I get it. Well, what we would be doing is we’d be seeing a lot of you. So, again, some of those visits she – you know, hopefully, the court stuff is better that she can come down with you. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Um. So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Do you want to get his opinion or her opinion about the trial? Um. Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And who knows what we may have by then too. If you don’t need it at all at that time. The, the I was going to sugg-propose that we do the prescreening and the blood test in anticipation of doing that testing for your blood today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that way we have at least that cooking… Family Member: Check the markers and? Doctor: Right. If the markers are positive, I think you should go on the Niraparib, the PARP inhibitor - the targeted treatment… Patient: Alright. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: If the markers are negative, then we’ll put you on that new hormone therapy study. Okay? Patient: Okay. Family Member: So sort of uh – Doctor: But if he can select out for something that might be to work from what we know right now, that’s worthwhile to me. Patient: Okay. So (clears throat)

Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: -you’re coming back. Call me a little hyper-anal. Doctor: Yes. Let’s do that. Doctor: I am. Good plan. Right? Plus it’ll keep you more on track if you know that you have to come in and we check your sugars and yeppers. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of-

Patient: All of whom. All of whom. All eight, including the, the black guy who did this study from Harvard, were convinced that they had Native American, uh, genes. None. (Laughs) Doctor: Well, you know, I, I did this myself. Ancest--I did Ancestry. Patient: Yeah. I might do that. Doctor: And, uh, I don’t know what they. I don’t know enough about what they use as a marker to say you’re --- Patient: Yeah, x-y-or z. Doctor: I want to say, I think Native American, there’s certain mutations that might come up that are only in Native American population. So, anyway, my, my story was my, my name is D_. My, there’s a town in England called D_. I had done my genealogy back to eighteen twenty. Until, you know, my --- two generations ago came to America, multiple generations lived in England. Patient: Do you know that for sure? Doctor: Were married to people in England, had children in England. So, I’m English, right? And, then, my moth --- my grandmother’s German. My grandfather is English. So I’m going to do my Ancestry.com just to confirm, um, you know, those are my things. Family Member: I betcha you’re German, like us, yeah. Doctor: No English. I don’t even know how it’s possible because Doctor: It came back, like, I was German. My mother is Italian. That was there. The German was there, but it didn’t even mention English. And then, there was a little note, saying, “A low probability, four percent, English.” Like, no, that’s impossible because, English, English, English, English. Doctor: I see all of this, and I’m like, hmmm, I wonder if one of my great grandfathers is not English. (Laughs) Patient: He might have been a Norman.

Patient: Yep. For two weeks. Two weeks off, two weeks on. Doctor: You still on the Zoloda? Today? Patient: Yes. Doctor: per day any other medicine vitamins? Patient: Yes. Doctor: multivitamin steady today? Patient: two more pills; Optim- and two more pills Patient: real small pill Doctor: It’s a eye drop or a pill? Patient: It’s a pill. Oral. (pause) Doctor: The , how much do you take of that? Patient: I think it’s ten milligrams, small Doctor: One capsule a day?

Patient: Oh man, come on listen you gotta understand something doc, you got to be able to share the wealth and be a cheerful giver. DOC; Mm, hmm. Doctor: Yeah, we’re gonna definitely go over the results don’t you worry. Patient: Yeah. yeah. Doctor: They’re the spots in the back. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It still is that one area. Patient: It, it it ain’t moved at all? Doctor: No. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: I’m very glad just like W___ that it’s not in your hip. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: You already say Dr. P___ a while ago do you remember that for your back. Patient: Yes. Yes.

Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.
